dialogueacts.text: Okay , so basically I'm gonna present some findings of a study we conducted uh into uh what users want in this remote control .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: Um so first of all we <disfmarker> what we did is we um conducted a an experiment with a hundred test subjects .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: Um we put them in a in our um usability laboratory and got them to , you know , um play with remote controls ,
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: and also to complete , after they'd done that , to complete a questionnaire uh to tell us what they like and what they don't like in remote controls .

dialogueacts.speaker: A
dialogueacts.text: Oh , you can put it here .

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: So basically um the major things we found out was that um basically users don't like the look and feel of of most remote controls that are currently on the market .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: seventy five percent of the people we we uh did the experiments on , found that rem remote the remote controls that they'd used in the past were ugly .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: Um they they didn't match the operating behaviour of the user ,
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: that is , you know , the the way users use remote controls when they're watching T_V_ .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: Um , that the layout of the remote controls didn't match they way that they used it .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: Um and thirdly they say that w half of the users that we um tested said that they only used ten percent of the buttons that uh are on remote controls .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: we also some collected some usage statistics uh based on how these test subjects were using their remote control .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: And from this we basically came up with the figure that the channel buttons , the channel selection buttons are the most <disfmarker> by far the most used buttons on the remote control .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: Um and you can see they're used a hundred and sixty eight times per hour on average , um , while the user's watching T_V_ .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: Um the closest button that was used ,

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: well the cl the button that was used that was closest to the channel button was the teletext button ,

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: um which was used fourteen times per hour ,
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: followed by the volume button , which was four times per hour , um ,
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: all the other , all the other um buttons , such as ch um audio and picture selection um configuration buttons and things were used , you know , l approx well less than or equal to one times per hour .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: Um we also asked users um which buttons had the most importance to them ,
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: you know , which which buttons they felt were the most important buttons on on the remote control .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: And basically they came <disfmarker> they said the channel , volume , and power buttons had the highest relevance to users ,
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: um note that only power was very infrequently used , it only had a b a a fr usage frequency of about one times per hour , but users ranked it as having a very very high relevance .

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: Um and the audio and picture settings had a very <disfmarker>
dialogueacts.label: stl

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: that well the users thought that um w the audio and picture settings were very uh weren't very important to them um ,
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: and they used them very infrequently a as well .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: <vocalsound> So we asked users what what um frustrates them the most about um current remote controls .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: And fifty percent of the users said that uh what frustrates them is losing the remote control um somewhere in the room and not being able to find it .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: Um <vocalsound> they also said that it um it takes a lot of time to learn a new remote control ,
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: especially when there's many buttons and it's a , you know , a c a a unintuitive interface .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: Um and then thirdly , they <disfmarker> some users commented on the fact that the the you know the way that you have to hold and press buttons on a remote control ar are bad and um cause u repetitive strain injury .

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: <vocalsound> We also asked some users about some specific features that they'd like to see in the <disfmarker> on the remote control .

dialogueacts.speaker: D
dialogueacts.text: they want these high technology features .

dialogueacts.speaker: D
